A Smithsonian magazine special report
Months Before Rosa Parks Made Headlines, Claudette Colvin Refused to Give Up Her Seat for a White Woman on a Segregated Bus
Colvin, a lesser-known figure who took a stand against racial discrimination as a teenager in Montgomery, Alabama, has died at age 86
Claudette Colvin, widely considered an unsung hero of the American civil rights movement, has died at age 86.
“To us, she was more than a historical figure. She was the heart of our family, wise, resilient and grounded in faith,” according to a January 13 statement from the Claudette Colvin Foundation. “We will remember her laughter, her sharp wit, and her unwavering belief in justice and human dignity.”
At age 15, Colvin was arrested after she refused to give up her seat to a white woman on a segregated city bus in Montgomery, Alabama, on March 2, 1955. She went on to become one of four Black plaintiffs in a successful federal lawsuit against the city’s bus system, Browder v. Gayle, which ultimately paved the way for the end of segregation on public transportation across the nation.
But months later, Colvin’s defiant gesture was overshadowed by a similar act of resistance by Rosa Parks, who became known as the “mother of the civil rights movement.”
For decades, Colvin kept quiet about the role she played in the movement. “My mother told me to be quiet about what I did,” Colvin explained to the New York Times’ Brooks Barnes in 2009. “She told me, ‘Let Rosa be the one. White people aren’t going to bother Rosa—her skin is lighter than yours, and they like her.’”
But eventually, Colvin began to open up—and in recent years, she started to gain more recognition. In 2009, Phillip Hoose wrote a biography called Claudette Colvin: Twice Toward Justice, which won the National Book Award for Young People’s Literature that year. In 2010, the street she lived on as a child was renamed “Claudette Colvin Drive,” and in 2017, the city of Montgomery named March 2 as “Claudette Colvin Day.” Two years later, the city unveiled two commemorative markers in honor of Colvin and the other plaintiffs in Browder v. Gayle.
In 2021, when Colvin was 82, her juvenile record stemming from the bus protest was expunged. That same year, a colorful mural dedicated to Colvin was unveiled on Claudette Colvin Drive.
Quick facts: The day Colvin cleared her record
- Colvin filed the request at a clerk’s office in Montgomery on October 6, 2021.
- “I guess you can say that now I am no longer a juvenile delinquent,” she told a crowd of supporters, per the Associated Press.
Colvin was born Claudette Austin on September 5, 1939, in Birmingham. As a child, she was sent to live with her great-aunt and uncle, Mary Ann and Quentiss P. Colvin, and eventually adopted their last name. The family moved to King Hill, an African-American neighborhood in Montgomery, when Colvin was 8, according to the Times’ Clay Risen.
As a student at the segregated Booker T. Washington High School, she learned about civil rights and became involved in the NAACP Youth Council. On March 2, 1955, she was riding a Montgomery city bus when the driver ordered her to vacate her seat in a section known as “no man’s land,” meant to serve as a buffer between the whites-only seats at the front and Black riders at the back.
Colvin was sitting in a row with three other Black riders when a white woman boarded the bus. Two of the other Black riders moved right away, followed soon after by the third. But Colvin stayed rooted in place.
“Whenever people ask me ‘Why didn’t you get up when the bus driver asked you?’ I say it felt as though Harriet Tubman’s hands were pushing me down on one shoulder and Sojourner Truth’s hands were pushing me down on the other shoulder,” Colvin told BBC World Service’s Taylor-Dior Rumble in 2018. “I felt inspired by these women because my teacher taught us about them in so much detail.”
The driver called the police, who forcibly removed her from the bus and shoved her into a police car. They drove her to the station, making vulgar remarks about her appearance along the way.
Colvin was charged and convicted in juvenile court for disturbing the peace, violating segregation laws and assaulting a police officer. Fred Gray, her lawyer, appealed the conviction and got the first two charges dropped. But the third stuck, and Colvin was sentenced to probation and ordered to pay a fine.
Local civil rights leaders considered making Colvin the face of the fight against racial discrimination. However, “they worried they couldn’t win with her,” Hoose told the Times in 2009. “Words like ‘mouthy,’ ‘emotional’ and ‘feisty’ were used to describe her.” In contrast, Parks, who refused to give up her seat on a Montgomery bus on December 1, was seen as “stolid, calm, unflappable.” Her arrest sparked the 13-month Montgomery Bus Boycott, led by Martin Luther King Jr., which became a pivotal moment in the civil rights movement.
Colvin, meanwhile, became a star witness in Browder v. Gayle, which challenged the segregation of Montgomery’s buses. The case made it all the way to the U.S. Supreme Court, which in 1956 affirmed a lower court’s ruling that bus segregation was unconstitutional.
Afterward, Colvin felt alienated from both the Black and white communities of Montgomery, as PBS News reported in 2009. She moved to New York, where she spent decades quietly raising her two sons and working as a nurse’s aide. She almost never talked about her past.
It was only after she retired in 2004 that she began to speak publicly about her experiences as a teen, per the Encyclopedia of Alabama. Hoose, who wrote the 2009 biography, spent years trying to convince her to tell her story, per the Times.
In a statement, Montgomery mayor Steven Reed lauded Colvin for laying “the legal and moral foundation for the movement that would change America,” per WSFA 12 News’ Valorie Lawson.
“For decades, her bravery was too often overlooked,” he said. “Claudette Colvin’s life reminds us that movements are built not only by those whose names are most familiar, but by those whose courage comes early, quietly and at great personal cost.”

articles.content:
See a 157-Year-Old Great Lakes Shipwreck in Stunning Detail With This New 3D Scan
Last year, maritime archaeologists revisited the “Northerner” in Lake Michigan and captured hundreds of still images, which they stitched together to create a digital replica of the vessel
On November 28, 1868, an American schooner called the Northerner was loading up with cargo near Cedar Grove, Wisconsin, when its hull became badly damaged. The next day, while being towed to Milwaukee for repairs, the vessel filled with water and sank to the bottom of Lake Michigan. The ship’s crew members were rescued, but the vessel was never recovered.
Now, 157 years later, experts have produced a highly detailed 3D digital scan that gives users a chance to virtually explore the shipwreck as it rests on the lakebed. Created by stitching together 1,670 still images, the replica even shows the Northerner’s final load of cordwood still in its hull.
The 81.1-foot-long vessel was built in Clayton, New York, in 1850 by John Oades, one of the most experienced shipbuilders on the lakes at the time. The ship initially set sail on Lake Ontario, ferrying supplies to communities on the American and Canadian shores. Later in her career, the ship transported lumber on Lake Michigan.
It was during one of those lumber-carrying missions that the vessel endured irreparable damage. While loading up with cordwood at Amsterdam, the vessel “pounded heavily upon the bottom” at the pier, according to a November 1868 Milwaukee Sentinel report shared by the Wisconsin Shipwrecks database.
The ship was leaking badly, so the captain navigated south to Port Washington and unloaded the cargo that was being stored on the deck. However, his efforts proved futile. While being towed by another vessel, the Cuyahoga, the ship filled with water and capsized near Port Ulao, a historic port located roughly 20 miles north of Milwaukee.
The shipwreck was initially discovered by divers in the early 1970s. But it wasn’t until 2009 that the Wisconsin Historical Society’s Maritime Preservation and Archaeology Program officially recorded its location. In 2010, it was listed on the National Register of Historic Places, and in 2021 it became part of the newly designated Wisconsin Shipwreck Coast National Marine Sanctuary.
Today, the vessel is still largely intact. It rests upright, submerged roughly 135 feet deep, making it a popular destination for recreational scuba divers. In 2024, crews installed buoys and mooring lines near 19 of the most popular shipwrecks at the sanctuary—including the Northerner—to make the sites easier to locate and safer to dive. The permanent mooring system also helps protect the lakebed from damage caused by anchors and grappling hooks, since they give dive boats a place to tie up.
Last year, maritime archaeologists and engineers embarked on a weeklong expedition to survey some of the Great Lakes’ deepest wrecks, many of which are rapidly deteriorating because of invasive quagga mussels. Their first stop was the relatively shallow Northerner, where they tested out an autonomous underwater vehicle equipped with high-tech underwater imaging instruments.
Using the Saab Sabertooth robot, they captured highly detailed images of the wreck, which they later digitally merged to create the new 3D model.
The images revealed some fresh insights about the wreck. For the first time, for example, researchers spotted the Northerner’s rigging, which is located roughly 60 feet away from the rest of the vessel, as Caitlin Looby reported for the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel last year.
Quick fact: Shipwrecks in the Great Lakes
Thousands of ships have sunk in the Great Lakes, including roughly 600 vessels in Lake Michigan alone.
“We know less about Lake Michigan than we thought we did,” Russ Green, superintendent of the sanctuary, told the Milwaukee Journal Sentinel. “As we push deeper into Lake Michigan, we need autonomous technology to help us figure out what's going on down there.”
Marine archaeologists have created similar 3D replicas of other vessels, including Ernest Shackleton’s Endurance. The vessel sank on November 21, 1915, after getting stuck in pack ice and has been resting on the seafloor near Antarctica ever since. In 2024, experts released a 3D model created from more than 25,000 high-resolution images captured after the iconic vessel was discovered in 2022. The Endurance scan is so detailed it even shows everyday items used by the crew, such as dining plates and a boot.
You can also explore 3D models of dozens of shipwrecks within Thunder Bay National Marine Sanctuary, a 4,300-square-mile protected area of Lake Huron.

articles.title: This Mysterious Gas Cloud Spotted Around a Dead Star Is Beautiful—but Astronomers Say It Shouldn’t Be There

The stellar corpse is spewing star stuff, which is heating and compressing surrounding gas,...
articles.content:
This Mysterious Gas Cloud Spotted Around a Dead Star Is Beautiful—but Astronomers Say It Shouldn’t Be There
The stellar corpse is spewing star stuff, which is heating and compressing surrounding gas, resulting in a multicolored display. But it’s missing a component thought to be necessary for this phenomenon
Astronomers have discovered something that, according to current knowledge, shouldn’t exist. They took snapshots of a colorful yet perplexing shock wave around a white dwarf, the leftover core of a dying star.
The object has been spewing star stuff to create this colorful arc for at least 1,000 years, but it’s missing something that was previously thought to be a crucial component, according to a study published January 12 in the journal Nature Astronomy.
White dwarf RXJ0528+2838 resides about 730 light-years from Earth and has a companion star orbiting it, which sends material to the dense core. In similar binary systems, the donated star material forms a disc around the white dwarf, which then funnels onto the stellar corpse. Some of the disc matter gets shot into space, creating strong outflows, and, sometimes, shock waves.
“A shock wave is created when fast-moving material plows into surrounding gas, suddenly compressing and heating it,” which also makes it colorful, study co-author Simone Scaringi, an astrophysicist at Durham University in England, tells Reuters’ Will Dunham. The type seen around RXJ0528+2838 is called a bow shock, which is “the curved shock front that forms when an object moves rapidly through space, similar to the wave in front of a boat moving through water,” he adds.
Scaringi and his colleagues first noticed a strange cloud of gas and dust, or nebula, around RXJ0528+2838 when they peered at it with the Isaac Newton Telescope in Spain. That prompted follow-up observations with the Very Large Telescope in Chile, which took snapshots of the multicolored bow shock around the white dwarf. The colors represent different elements, with red coming from hydrogen, green from nitrogen and blue from oxygen, Reuters reports.
Quick fact: The Very Large Telescope
The Very Large Telescope sits on a mountaintop in northern Chile. It’s operated by the European Southern Observatory, an astrophysics organization supported by 16 nations, and it has been observing the sky in visible-light wavelengths and beyond since 1998.
But the object was missing a surrounding disc of star material, the team found, thought to be necessary to create shock waves. “The surprise that a supposedly quiet, discless system could drive such a spectacular nebula was one of those rare ‘wow’ moments,” Scaringi says in a statement.
What’s more, the colorful shock wave is huge, with an estimated length about 3,800 times the distance between Earth and the sun, according to a separate statement. Analysis of its size and shape suggests the white dwarf has been spitting out material for at least a millennium.
Although the situation has puzzled the team, they suspect the white dwarf’s known strong magnetic field might play a role in the enduring outflow. Computer simulations suggest the field might help the white dwarf pull material from the companion star and directly add the stolen stuff onto itself, skipping the disc step. However, the analysis found that the shock wave should last only around 600 years.
Still, the observation challenges researchers’ current understanding of how stellar corpses interact with their environments. “It is a powerful reminder of how incomplete our understanding of the physics powering bow shocks still is,” study co-author Martina Veresvarska, an astrophysicist at Durham University, says in a different statement.

Named “Cloud-9,” the discovery is a new type of celestial object known as a...

Astronomers Find an Odd Space Cloud, Like a Galaxy Without Stars, That Could Shed Light on the Secrets of Dark Matter
Named “Cloud-9,” the discovery is a new type of celestial object known as a RELHIC, that is unlike anything scientists have ever observed
Astronomers have discovered a new type of cosmic object: a gas-rich cloud about 14 million light-years away from our planet that could help illuminate the mysteries of the dark universe. Nicknamed “Cloud-9,” it looks a lot like a typical galaxy, but it’s missing a key ingredient.
The object appears to be starless, according to a study published in The Astrophysical Journal Letters in November and presented at a meeting of the American Astronomical Society last week—a finding that might make Cloud-9 the first known example of a RELHIC, or Reionization-Limited H I Cloud. These theoretical objects are thought to be the remnants of failed galaxies from the early universe that couldn’t attract enough gas to form stars.
“It’s basically a galaxy that wasn’t,” Rachael Beaton, a study co-author and astronomer at the Space Telescope Science Institute, said at the meeting, per Katrina Miller at the New York Times. “There’s nothing like this that we’ve found so far in the universe.”
Cloud-9 was first spotted in 2023 by the Five-hundred-meter Aperture Spherical Telescope, a radio observatory in China. At the time, scientists weren’t yet sure what they were looking at. The object appeared to completely lack stars, and subsequent observations by telescopes in the United States found the same thing. But it was still possible that ground-based observatories simply weren’t strong enough to make out stars in Cloud-9, which could have been a faint dwarf galaxy.
So, astronomers turned to the Hubble Space Telescope—and again found no clear evidence of stars. Their findings only revealed a hint to one potential star, which has not been confirmed. The work “certainly eliminates the possibility that [Cloud-9] is a dwarf galaxy,” Kristine Spekkens, an astronomer at Queen’s University in Canada, who was not involved in the study, tells Jenna Ahart at Scientific American.
“It’s clear that there is no substantial amount of stars here,” says Gagandeep Anand, an astronomer at the Space Telescope Science Institute, who led the work, to the New York Times.
Importantly, the study also offers insight into dark matter, the invisible force that is thought to make up 85 percent of the universe’s mass.
Did you know? The dark universe
- Dark matter is invisible, because it doesn’t interact with light—it doesn’t absorb, emit or reflect electromagnetic waves, such as infrared, ultraviolet and visible light. But it does interact with gravity, so astronomers can see its effects on the universe.
- Dark energy is an unknown, mysterious force that’s driving the universe’s accelerating expansion.
By analyzing radio waves emitted by the gas in Cloud-9, the authors found that the object has a core of neutral hydrogen with one million times the mass of our sun. That’s not enough mass to hold the cloud together, the scientists suggest, so they calculated that Cloud-9 must be surrounded by a halo of dark matter totaling about five billion solar masses to provide gravitational support.
“This cloud is a window into the dark universe,” says Andrew Fox, a study co-author and astronomer at the Space Telescope Science Institute, in a statement. “We know from theory that most of the mass in the universe is expected to be dark matter, but it’s difficult to detect this dark material because it doesn’t emit light. Cloud-9 gives us a rare look at a dark matter-dominated cloud.”
RELHICs are thought to be dark matter clouds, per the statement, making them easily outshined by nearby objects and, therefore, difficult to study. As such, researchers still have a lot to learn about Cloud-9. Spekkens tells Scientific American that the cloud doesn’t have the smooth shape astronomers would expect. And by getting a better understanding of its gas distribution, she says, astronomers could paint a clearer picture of how the RELHIC formed and evolved.
If it were a lot bigger—such as more than five billion times the mass of the sun—it would have become a galaxy. If it were a lot smaller, the gas would have dispersed, leaving essentially nothing behind. Instead, the cloud sits in a “sweet spot,” per the statement, where it can endure as a RELHIC.
Cloud-9 isn’t necessarily doomed to be a failure forever. It could still gather enough mass to become a galaxy, though scientists aren’t sure how that would happen.
No matter its fate, Anand tells the New York Times that he believes more objects like Cloud-9 are out there, waiting to be discovered. “This is just the first one we’ve found,” he adds. “There have got to be others like it.”
